Section.title: Package Format 1.0 Specification

Subsection.title: Overview
Subsection.Paragraph: This section specifies the format of version 1.0 montarre packages.

This specification is divided into an abstract model and a separate serialization. The purpose of the model is to describe the semantics of montarre packages; the actual meaning of the data within, and to describe properties and invariants that must be true for all valid montarre packages. The serialization section describes the on-disk formats used for distribution.

The formal specification described here is written in the Gallina specification language of the Coq theorem prover. The language is a total, pure-functional, dependently-typed language allowing for describing systems in rigorous detail including machine-checked proofs of various chosen properties.
The full sources of the entire specification are published at the end of this section.

Subsection.title: Regular Expressions
Subsection.Paragraph:
The specification makes use of regular expressions to specify the required formats of some string types. The regular expression language used should be assumed to be the
Java regular expression language.
The specification itself axiomatizes regular expressions using the following definitions:

Subsection.title: Dotted Strings
Subsection.Paragraph: A Lanark dotted string is a string conforming to the regular expression given in the Lanark specification.

Subsection.title: Language
Subsection.Paragraph: A language value is an IETF BCP 47 language tag identifying a language.
Example language values include: "en", "yi-Hebr", "gsw-u-sd-chzh".

Subsection.title: TranslatedText
Subsection.Paragraph: A translated text value is a record consisting of a piece of text in a specified language, along with a map consisting of translations of that text indexed by language.

Subsection.title: Overview
Subsection.Paragraph: A hash is a record consisting of an algorithm and a value.

Subsection.title: Algorithm
Subsection.Paragraph:
A hash algorithm specifies the name of a cryptographic hash algorithm. The names must be taken from the
Java message digest algorithm name specification.

Subsection.title: Value
Subsection.Paragraph: A hash value is an ASCII, lowercase, hexadecimal text serialization of the binary output of a hash algorithm.

Subsection.title: Architecture Name
Subsection.Paragraph: An architecture name is a unique name for a particular hardware architecture. It represents an attempt to provide a consistent naming convention for hardware types .
An architecture name is a string conforming to the regular expression [a-z][a-z0-9_-]{0,32}.
This specification recognizes the following architecture names:
The special name unknown is assigned to unrecognized hardware architectures. The unknown name is not permitted to appear in package declarations.

Subsection.title: Operating System Name
Subsection.Paragraph: An operating system name is a unique name for a particular operating system. It represents an attempt to provide a consistent naming convention for operating systems.
An operating system name is a string conforming to the regular expression [a-z][a-z0-9_-]{0,32}.
This specification recognizes the following operating system names:
The special name unknown is assigned to unrecognized operating systems. The unknown name is not permitted to appear in package declarations.

Subsection.title: Platform
Subsection.Paragraph: A platform is a record consisting of an architecture name and operating system name.

Subsection.title: Package
Subsection.Paragraph: A montarre package contains a single package declaration which specifies metadata and a manifest.

Subsection.title: Overview
Subsection.Paragraph: The metadata for the package is a record describing the package itself. It provides important information pertaining to the identity of the package, information pertaining to the runtime environment required to run the package, and information used to produce listings in packaging environments such as Flatpak.

Subsection.title: ApplicationKind
Subsection.Paragraph: The application kind of a package is one of the following values:

Row.Cell: The application is a text-only console application.
The application is a graphical application.

Subsection.title: Categories
Subsection.Paragraph: A category is a string conforming to the regular expression [A-Z][A-Za-z0-9_-]{0,128}. A package has zero or more categories.

Categories should be taken from the
Freedesktop.org category registry.
Example category values include: "Building", "Development".

Subsection.title: Overview
Subsection.Paragraph: The copying information for a package is a record consisting of a license and a copyright.

Subsection.title: License
Subsection.Paragraph: A license is an SPDX license identifier denoting the license of the package.
Example license values include: "ISC", "Apache-2.0", "BSD-3-Clause", "GPL-3.0-or-later".

Subsection.title: Copyright
Subsection.Paragraph: A copyright is a simple copyright string that indicates the current holder of the copyright on the package.
An example copyright value is: "Copyright © 2024 Mark Raynsford <code@io7m.com> https://www.io7m.com".

Subsection.title: Description
Subsection.Paragraph: A description is a short translated text that provides a summary of the package.

Subsection.title: Overview
Subsection.Paragraph: The Flatpak information for a package provides extra metadata used to produce Flatpaks.

Subsection.title: Runtimes
Subsection.Paragraph: A Flatpak runtime consists of a name, a version, and a role.
Roles may be one of the following values:

Subsection.title: Permissions
Subsection.Paragraph: A Flatpak permission denotes that the named permission will be granted to the application when it runs as a Flatpak.
Example permission values include: "--share=net", "--socket=x11".

Subsection.title: Overview
Subsection.Paragraph: The java info information for a package is a record consisting of a required JDK version and a main module.

Subsection.title: Required JDK Version
Subsection.Paragraph: The required JDK version specifies the lower bound of the major version of the Java runtime required to use this package.

Subsection.title: Main Module
Subsection.Paragraph: The main module specifies the fully-qualified name of the application's main class.
An example main module value is: "com.io7m.montarre.cmdline/com.io7m.montarre.cmdline.MMain".

Subsection.title: Overview
Subsection.Paragraph: A link is a target reference to an external website or entity, along with a role describing the relationship between that entity and the package.
The target of a link must be a valid RFC 3986 URI.

Subsection.title: Roles
Subsection.Paragraph: A role is one of the following values:

Row.Cell: A link to an issue tracker.
A link to a home page.
A link to a donation page.
A link to a contact page.
A link to an FAQ page.
A link to a translation page.
A link to a contribution page.
A link to an SCM repository.

Subsection.title: Overview
Subsection.Paragraph: The long description information for a package is a set of paragraphs and features. A long description has an associated language and there may be at most one long description per language in a given package.

Subsection.title: Paragraph
Subsection.Paragraph: A paragraph is a humanly readable description of some aspect of the package for marketing purposes.

Subsection.title: Feature
Subsection.Paragraph: A feature is a humanly readable description of one of the features provided by the package for marketing purposes.

Subsection.title: Overview
Subsection.Paragraph: The names information for a package is a record consisting of a set of different types of names for the package.

Subsection.title: Package Name
Subsection.Paragraph: The package name is a unique identifier for the package, specified as a dotted string.
Example package name values include: "com.io7m.montarre", "com.io7m.lanark".

Subsection.title: Human Name
Subsection.Paragraph: The human name is a friendly, human-readable name for the package.
An example human name value is "Montarre".

Subsection.title: Short Name
Subsection.Paragraph: An example short name value is "montarre".

Subsection.title: Overview
Subsection.Paragraph: The vendor information for a package is a record consisting of a vendor name and a unique vendor ID.

Subsection.title: Name
Subsection.Paragraph: The vendor name is the humanly-readable name of the vendor of the package, conforming to the regular expression [a-zA-Z][A-Za-z0-9_-]{0,128} .

Subsection.title: ID
Subsection.Paragraph: The vendor ID is a unique identifier for the vendor of the package, specified as a dotted string.
Example vendor ID values include: "com.io7m", "com.example".

Subsection.title: Overview
Subsection.Paragraph: The version information for a package is a record consisting of a version number and a version/release date.

Subsection.title: Number
Subsection.Paragraph: The version number is the semantic version of the package.

Subsection.title: Date
Subsection.Paragraph: The version date is an ISO 8601 date string denoting the release date of this version of the package.
Example version date values include: "2024-10-13", "2001-01-23".

Subsection.title: Overview
Subsection.Paragraph: A manifest consists of a set of items.
An item is a Module, PlatformModule, or a Resource.
Items within a manifest must have unique file names. More formally, for a manifest m, there cannot exist two different items i0 and i1 in m such that i0 and i1 have filenames that are the same.
Each item carries a hash value denoting the cryptographic hash of the contents of the item within the package.

Subsection.title: FileName
Subsection.Paragraph: A file name is a unique name assigned to a manifest item. File names are case-insensitive strings that conform to the regular expression ([\p{L}\p{N}_\-.+]+)(/[\p{L}\p{N}_\-.+]+)*

Intuitively, a filename can be considered to be a non-empty /-separated list of file name segments that each conform to the regular expression [\p{L}\p{N}_\-.+]+. Accordingly, filenames cannot start with slashes, cannot end with trailing slashes, and cannot contain sequences of repeating slashes.

Subsection.title: Modules
Subsection.Paragraph: A module represents a platform-neutral jar file that will be placed onto the Java module path regardless of the underlying hardware architecture and operating system on which the application is running.

Subsection.title: PlatformModules
Subsection.Paragraph: A platform module represents a platform-specific jar file that will be placed onto the Java module path when the hardware architecture and operating system of the module matches that of the platform upon which the application is running.

Subsection.title: Resources
Subsection.Paragraph: A resource is an arbitrary file associated with the package. Resources are typically used to provide icons, BOMs, and screenshots for the package.
A resource has an associated role that describes the purpose of the resource.
A role has one of the following values:

Row.Cell: A bill-of-materials. Recommended to be in CycloneDX format.

Subsection.Paragraph: A resource has an associated caption that provides a human-readable description of the resource. This is used, for example, to describe the contents of screenshots for use in Flatpak listings.

Subsection.title: Overview
Subsection.Paragraph: montarre package declarations are serialized to an XML format with a strict XSD schema. The serialized package declaration, and all the package contents, are collected into a ZIP file with some extra restrictions on the entries. Extra restrictions are applied to the ZIP container and the XML data to assist with ensuring that montarre packages are reproducible.

Subsection.title: ZIP
Subsection.Paragraph: montarre packages are ZIP files with the file extension .mpk. The following restrictions are applied to the entries of the ZIP file:

ListUnordered.Item: All entry names in the ZIP file must be valid file names.
All entry names in the ZIP file must be transformed to uppercase in a neutral locale.
All entries must be written with creation, modification, and last access dates of 2024-10-14T00:00:00Z.
All entries, except for the first entry, must be written such that their names appear in ascending alphabetical order.
The first entry in the file must be META-INF/MONTARRE/PACKAGE.XML.

Subsection.Paragraph: The package declaration is serialized to XML and stored in the META-INF/MONTARRE/PACKAGE.XML entry in the ZIP file.

Subsection.title: XML
Subsection.Paragraph: Package declarations must be serialized according to the included schema with the following restrictions:

ListUnordered.Item: XML must be serialized indented to four spaces.

The character content of elements must be serialized using a function equivalent to XSLT's
normalize-space()
function.

After indenting, XML must be canonicalized using the
Exclusive XML Canonicalization Version 1.0
algorithm.

Section.Footnote: Vendor names are used in some native packaging systems as installation directories and are therefore required to be filesystem-safe.
Short names are used in some native packaging systems as executable names and are therefore required to be filesystem-safe.
Many hardware architectures have different names referring to the same thing. For example, 64-bit x86 hardware is often referred to as amd64, x64, x86_64, etc.
